conversation.content: So, um, when you think back, you know, to those early days, which, er, numbers stand out most clearly?
Well, honestly, it's 47 - that's how many, um, days I went without electricity that first winter, counting each one like, you know, marking territory I'd survived.
That must have felt endless in the moment.
It stretched like taffy, each day pulling longer than the last, but now those 47 days feel compressed into this dense little nugget of resilience I carry everywhere.
Were there other numbers that became anchors?
Oh absolutely - like, 3 was huge, actually, because that's how many, err, meals I could squeeze from one, basically, chicken when things got really tight.
The precision of survival, hmm, becomes [cry] its own, you know, kind of poetry, I guess.
Exactly - you start seeing life in these mathematical terms, like 14 steps to the water pump, 6 matches left in the box, 2 blankets between 4 people.
Did, uh, counting become, sort of, a coping mechanism or more like, anyway, a way to maintain control?
Both really - so, counting was my, umm, meditation and my anchor, right so, giving structure to chaos when everything else felt, you know, completely unmoored.
I imagine, well, certain numbers, er, still trigger memories even now, honestly.

Oh they do - like, I can't see 23 without, uhh, remembering that's how old I was, basically, when everything fell apart, or hear 89 without thinking, you know, about my neighbor's apartment number where I'd go for help.
The way you [cough] describe it makes each number feel sacred somehow.
They became my rosary beads in a way - each one holding a specific prayer or promise, a moment I survived that proved I could survive the next one too.
Do you, actually, ever find yourself still, um, counting things unconsciously, like, out of old habit?

All the time - I count [very sad] stairs, heartbeats, seconds between thunderclaps, it's this quiet arithmetic that keeps me grounded, reminding me I made it through when the counting really mattered.
The way, err, you've transformed that, basically, trauma into something, hmm, almost beautiful is remarkable.
Well, you have to, uhh, find beauty [sneeze] somewhere or the weight of it all, you know, becomes unbearable - so, those numbers became my art, actually, my proof of persistence.
What number, um, means the most to you now, like, looking back at, well, everything?
It's 1,825 - so, that's how many days it took, honestly, to feel human again, and I, er, cherish every single one because, you know, each was a choice to keep going.
